Much more vital is the problem of continuing support* There must be large amounts
of money each year flowing into an educational television station if it survives*
It must come from earned income of some kind, from heavy endowments, or from a
substantial tax base or other source of regular public income* I can see no

THE SEMANTIC BARBIER—1"COMMERCIAL AMD NON-CC^IERCIAL"
*My strength is as the strength of ten because ray heart is pure*"
—Sir Galahad
There is a belief, strongly held in many education circles, that the "Galahad
energy law" applies directly to non-commercial TV stations* This belief
overlooks certain considerations, e*g* the good knight wore armor, he had a
sword, and presumably ate large quantities of protein to maintain his initial
strength* When he setfbrth to do deeds of valor and virtue he was physically
equipped in much the same manner as a "bad knight" and hi© techniques in
battle probably did not differ greatly from that of his various opponents*
His motivations, however, were quite different and his goals ware praiseworthy*
Too many educators seem to cherish the illusion that theyare completely unique
when they embark on station operation* The fact is that they,generally speaking,
will not create new laws and procedures but will follow special applications
of existing techniques and procedures in television canmunication* The educator
is special in his credo, devotion, and resource, not in technique* He is special
in his willingness to use ALL of the techniques instead of a stereotyped few*
He is special in his willingness to select and prepare and display that which
is best and most significant and most meaningful to the people of our society*
But he must first be a good broadcaster or telecaster before he can be a good
educational broadcaster or educational telecaster* He is subject to the pro¬
cedural limitations and requirements of television, many of which have been
adopted for the same reason as the conventions of the theatre* The significant
item is the content and the purpose not thestago, but the physical and fiscal
requirements for making the educational displays available to the public do
not differ essentially from the physical requirements the commercial broad¬
caster must recognize and meet*
If we can acoept this concept we can save ourselves a lot of time expended in
useless controversy and questionable public relations.
